clinical_study.brief_title: Increasing Adherence to Pulmonary Rehabilitation After COPD Related Hospitalizations
clinical_study.official_title: Increasing Adherence to Pulmonary Rehabilitation After COPD Related Hospitalizations

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: This pilot study will look at investigating barriers and facilitators and comparative adherence and effectiveness between a home-based and a Center based Pulmonary Rehabilitation Program in patients who have recently been hospitalized for a COPD related cause.

detailed_description.textblock:
Despite proven benefits, the proportion of people with COPD who receive Pulmonary Rehabilitation (PR) is very small. The current model of a center-based PR program fails to address the needs of many patients with COPD. The most common patient barrier to attendance is travel to center-based programs, particularly for frail patients with more severe COPD who need transportation assistance. Home-based, unsupervised PR has been proposed as an alternative model to hospital-based programs and has been found to be safe and effective.
In this pilot study we will investigate barriers and facilitators for doing pulmonary rehabilitation either home-based or center based after a hospitalization. The results of this pilot study will inform an upcoming randomized control study under a different grant. Both quantitative and qualitative methods will be used for the evaluation.
The first 10 patients in this pilot study will not be randomized and allocated to home based PR in order to polish the intervention before the randomized portion of this pilot. This pilot is supported by a grant mechanism (R61) explicitly oriented to adjust the intervention for a future clinical study and identify barriers for not only in the intervention but also barriers for randomization.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Related Quality of Life as measured by the Chronic Respiratory Questionnaire (CRQ).
secondary_outcome.description: The CRQ will be completed by participants several times during the study. The questionnaire measures health related quality of life and is a validated tool. This questionnaire measures both physical and emotional aspects of chronic respiratory disease. Higher scores indicate better health related quality of life. (numerical, 1-7 point Likert Scale, emotional and physical summary scores will be reported )
The Self-Management Ability Scale (30) item questionnaire that measures ability and function. A higher score indicates more ability and function in everyday life.
Number of ER and Hospital visits/days

secondary_outcome.measure: Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support
secondary_outcome.description: social support scale- 12 item questionnaire that measures the amount of social support and satisfaction with the support from the respondents perspective. A high score indicates a higher level of perceived support.
Investigate barriers and facilitators to PR adherence

arm_group.description: Home-based Pulmonary Rehabilitation (PR) with health coaching using a remote system that will allow patients to complete PR at home. The program involves upper and lower extremity exercises, self-report of symptoms (fatigue, breathlessness, physical activity and overall well-being).
This arm receives the standard of care which may include PR at a facility. Traditional PR involves attending a medical center gym where they can do exercises and receive disease specific education.

intervention.description: Participants enrolled in the intervention arm will be offered a Home-based pulmonary rehabilitation program with health coaching.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria
- COPD related hospitalization and eligible for PR
- Exclusion Criteria
- Inability to walk (orthopedic-neurologic problems or confined to bed)
